instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
Board was repaired a few months ago with SMC replaced and some corrosion clean up, now is back.

PPBUS 8.6V
I get green then orange light on original charger.
I can trace the fluctuations as early as <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> this fluctuates around 1.1V to 1.8V.
Diode reading in all related rails are ok and no shorts found elsewhere on board.
Tried SMC bypass, clean BIOS, different SMC and new <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> with no luck.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuate around -1V from their normal values.
<CHIP>U7501</CHIP> Pin 23 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> is 8.6V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
Continuous fluctuations, or you note them pulsing every 3-5 seconds?
Any pulse at big coils, <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
For example <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> goes from 5V down to 2.3V in about 1 second then repeats, other mentioned rails do the same but with different voltage.

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is missing completely

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
Remove <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> and short its pad 1 to ground.
Test again mentioned voltages.
If no changes, do the same for <RESISTOR>R7552</RESISTOR>; test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message: With <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> pin shorted to grown I get same pulsing, with both <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7552</RESISTOR> PP5V stays steady but board does not boot and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> goes missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
If you remove <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> and short its pad 1 to ground, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is stable?
If yes, don't touch <RESISTOR>R7552</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message: With <RESISTOR>R5551</RESISTOR> removed and its pin 1 shorted to ground <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL> is still pulsing same as before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
Seems to have a problem with <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, or <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode to ground on both.
Be sure all components related with L/<TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> are good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> diode mode is on par with known good board.

Replaced L7560, <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7564</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7518</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7588</CAPACITOR> also measured all test points around <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> as well as all resistors, all measure fine too, but after all this I still get same behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message: Peak voltages repeats every 3-5s, or how?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message: As mentioned before for example <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> goes from 5V down to 2.3V in about 1 second then repeats, other mentioned rails do the same but with different voltage, so basically the voltages dont restart they fluctuate up and down fast and continue to repeat constantly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
Keep <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> disabled on <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> and remove <CHIP>U8020</CHIP>.
If still fluctuates, you have a problem with <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> power supply.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message:
Then seems to have a problem with <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Check diode mode there.
If good, replace <CHIP>U8020</CHIP> and try again.

Keep <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL> disabled for the moment.
Enable it if you get stable <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating
threads.message: Thanks so much, there was a bad cap in <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> that was bringing the line down a bit, replaced it and done!
